abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Investment Fund
            (SIF) Project for Bolivia were as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory, Bank performance was satisfactory, assessment
            outcome was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: while SIF has
            been considering ways to reduce its administrative costs, it
            is vital to find a proper measure of administrative
            efficiency that does not discourage the institution from
            undertaking innovative projects, attempting more complex
            interventions, emphasizing social participation in
            subprojects, and devoting the resources necessary to ensure
            the quality and sustainability of the project; SIF's
            information system, adapted from the ESF, was not, in
            hindsight, the most appropriate type of system for the SIF,
            nor was it able to successfully expand to keep pace with
            SIF's type or level of investment; it is vital to
            ensure that the accounting and information systems have the
            capacity to expand to meet projected investment levels, to
            provide extensive training in the use of the systems, and to
            regularly review the performance of the systems and make
            adjustments accordingly.
